message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Atrioventricular block is a common finding in atrial flutter. Option A is incorrect because the atrial rate in atrial flutter is generally between 250-350 beats per minute. Option B refers to the delta wave seen in Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, which is not associated with atrial flutter. Option D is also incorrect as there are P waves present in atrial flutter, although they may be difficult to discern.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Atrial flutter on an ECG is characterized by a sawtooth pattern with flutter waves and a regular ventricular rhythm. Atrioventricular (AV) block is commonly present in atrial flutter, and can be detected by the absence of a QRS complex following a P wave. Option (A) is incorrect because the atrial rate in atrial flutter is typically between 250-350 beats per minute. Option (B) is incorrect because a slurred upstroke of the R wave is characteristic of a delta wave in Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. Option (D) is incorrect because there are discernible flutter waves on an ECG in atrial flutter.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Atrial flutter is characterized by a rapid, regular atrial rhythm at a rate of 250 to 400 beats per minute, which produces atrial rates above 400 beats per minute. However, option (A) is not correct because the question asks for the most likely ECG finding. The slurred upstroke of R wave is a characteristic of a delta wave seen in Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome and not in atrial flutter. No discernible P waves are seen in atrial fibrillation, not in atrial flutter. Option (C), atrioventricular block, is often seen in atrial flutter due to the fixed conduction ratio between atrial and ventricular activity. So, option (C) is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Atrial flutter is characterized by a sawtooth pattern on ECG with a regular ventricular response, and there may be varying degrees of atrioventricular block. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer. Options (A) and (D) are also possible findings on ECG for atrial flutter, but they are not the most likely, and option (B) is a feature of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, which is a different condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of atrial flutter with regular tachycardia and absence of extra heart sounds on physical examination is consistent with Type I atrial flutter. Type I flutter is caused by a reentrant circuit located in the right atrium that involves the cavotricuspid isthmus. The ECG will show sawtooth waves and a fixed, consistent ventricular response. The most likely finding on the ECG will be atrioventricular block. This is because the atrial rate is usually much higher than the ventricular rate in atrial flutter, and the AV node will block some atrial impulses from reaching the ventricles.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Atrial flutter is characterized by a regular, rapid atrial rate and a slower ventricular rate due to varying degrees of AV block, so option (C) is the correct answer. Option (A) describes atrial fibrillation, not flutter. Option (B) describes the delta wave seen in Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, which is not present in this patient. Option (D) is also incorrect as atrial activity is present in atrial flutter, although it may manifest differently on ECG than in sinus rhythm.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Atrial flutter is characterized by a regular and rapid atrial rate (usually between 250 and 350 beats per minute) with a sawtooth appearance on ECG due to the presence of flutter waves. There may be a variable degree of atrioventricular block present. Slurred upstroke of R wave is seen in Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, which is not mentioned in the scenario. No discernible P waves are seen in atrial fibrillation, not atrial flutter.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Atrial flutter is usually characterized by a circuit conduction rate of around 240-340 beats per minute, which results in sawtooth-shaped flutter waves rather than discernible P waves. Slurred upstroke of R waves is seen in Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. Since the patient has a regular tachycardia, atrioventricular block is less likely to be present.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Atrial flutter is characterized by rapid, regular atrial depolarizations at rates between 250 and 450 bpm with a characteristic saw-toothed pattern on ECG. The most likely finding on ECG is atrioventricular block, which can occur due to the rapid and irregular atrial activity. Option A describes atrial fibrillation, and option B describes Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. Option D describes a lack of P waves, which can occur in atrial fibrillation or other atrial arrhythmias but is less commonly seen in atrial flutter.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Atrial flutter is characterized by rapid, regular atrial depolarizations at a rate of about 250 to 400 per minute, with an AV block. The options A and D are incorrect because the atrial rate is not consistently above 400 beats per minute, and P waves are present but sawtooth in appearance. The slurred upstroke of the R wave is associated with a delta wave found in Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome and is not related to atrial flutter.
